info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 36.

jeopardy_round: WE ALL SCREAM FOR ICE CREAM
ONE OF THE 12 TRIBES OF ISRAEL

(1, 1).clue: It's the decade in which Baskin-Robbins introduced the flavor "Beatle Nut" & "Here Comes the Fudge"

(2, 1).clue: Pulling no punches, it won awards for Best Picture, Actress, Supporting Actor & Director

(3, 1).clue: Laura Scudder didn't invent this taste treat but did invent a way to bag them so they could be a snack food staple

(4, 1).clue: The state where Ronald Reagan was born in 1911

(6, 1).clue: Maybe Sinatra was addressing Ava when he sang, "Call Me" this synonym for unreliable

(1, 2).clue: Ben & Jerry's has made lots of dough with the ice cream named for this "Dough", its No. 2 seller in 2004

(2, 2).clue: On accepting his award for Best Actor, Jamie Foxx thanked this man "for living"

(3, 2).clue: Dona Bailey co-created this arcade game where a leggy arthropod has to be removed from a mushroom patch

(4, 2).clue: The year he took up residence in the White House

(5, 2).clue: A corned beef & sauerkraut sandwich on rye

(6, 2).clue: Rather than "our debts", the Baltimore Catechism version of the Lord's prayer asks, "Forgive us" these

(1, 3).clue: The exotic-sounding name of this Bronx-born brand is meant "to convey an aura of... Old-World traditions"

(2, 3).clue: Sandy Powell must have been flying high after winning the Oscar for Costume Design for this film

(3, 3).clue: In 1921 Kate Gleason built 100 tract homes, inspired by a visit to an assembly line for these

(4, 3).clue: Nickname he gained from his role in "Knute Rockne--All American"

(6, 3).clue: King Xerxes crossed it in 480 B.C. to get to Europe

(1, 4).clue: From the Italian for "foam", it's a molded ice cream dessert that often contains candied fruit

(2, 4).clue: Original Screenplay honors went to... I can't remember... ah, yes, the writers of this Jim Carrey-Kate Winslet film
(2, 4).correct response: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind

(3, 4).clue: Patricia Bath has 4 patents for the laser that safely destroys this opacity of the eye's lens

(4, 4).clue: His term as president of this began in 1947

(5, 4).clue: It joins with "zooks!" as a mild or ironic oath

(6, 4).clue: Someone who verbally represents another person or product

(1, 5).clue: Bunny Tracks is a signature flavor from this "colorful" brand that makes folks feel "hoppy"

(2, 5).clue: Acknowledged for making such great movies as "Equus", "The Verdict" & "12 Angry Men", he received an honorary award

(3, 5).clue: Teri Pall claimed the 1965 invention of this device that had a range of 2 miles; we don't know if it was a 900 MHz

(4, 5).clue: The California city that's home to his presidential library & burial site

(5, 5).clue: Sans the San, Hearst's California castle

(6, 5).clue: A defendant in a divorce case

(1, 1).clue: During his career he produced about 240 paintings & drawings of the same woman--Helga Testorf

(2, 1).clue: This chatty cat belongs to the Duchess in "Alice in Wonderland"

(3, 1).clue: ...who had a No. 1 hit with "You've Got A Friend"

(5, 1).clue: A horse or a person impatient at being held back is said to do this

(6, 1).clue: (I'm Scott Van Pelt.)  When this ESPN "Big Show" debuted September 7, 1979, fans were told, "You've gone to sports heaven"

(1, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a slide of a painting.)  Arcimboldo portraits, using non-human elements, anticipate by 350 years this movement, founded in the 1920s

(2, 2).clue: In the poem "The Duel" there's a terrible spat between the Gingham Dog and this "Scrappy" cat

(3, 2).clue: ...who was the last president to be born in a log cabin

(5, 2).clue: All 435 square miles of it lie between the Adirondack & Green Mountains

(6, 2).clue: (Hi, I'm Dan Patrick.)  In 2004 this Colt was en fuego & the NFL was his "place" to throw a record 49 TD passes

(1, 3).clue: This New England painter once said, "Never put more than two waves in a picture; it's fussy"

(2, 3).clue: Claudine loves to read poems about kitties to Fanchette the cat in "Claudine and Annie" by this "Gigi" novelist

(3, 3).clue: The 2 Jameses who co-starred in the Hallmark Hall of Fame movies "Promise" & "My Name Is Bill W"

(5, 3).clue: Sadly, he died on the opening night of his last hit musical, "42nd Street"

(6, 3).clue: (Scott Van Pelt reads the clue.)  You can relive memories like 1977 NBA final games on the channel launched under this name in 1997

(1, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a slide of a painting.)  Géricault was just 21 in 1812 when he painted our next work, which displays the turbulence of this movement

(2, 4).clue: This woman's cat Sneaky Pie gets credit as her co-author on such mystery novels as "Murder, She Meowed"

(3, 4).clue: ...who conjured up Shangri-La for a 1933 novel

(5, 4).clue: Divided into 2 parts by the Rond-Point, it stretches 1.17 miles through Paris

(6, 4).clue: (Dan Patrick reads the clue.) From baseball, basketball & boxing, they were named by ESPN's "Sports Century" the 3 greatest North American Athletes of the 20th Century
(6, 4).correct response: Babe Ruth, Michael Jordan & Muhammad Ali

(1, 5).clue: In 1943 Jackson Pollock had his first solo exhibit at "Art of this Century", this woman's NYC gallery

(2, 5).clue: He wrote an "Ode on the Death of a Favorite Cat" (as well as that other famous "Elegy")

(5, 5).clue: The first "Farm Aid" relief concert was held in 1985 in this North-Central U.S. city

(6, 5).clue: (Scott Van Pelt reads the clue.)  When ESPN began here in Connecticut in 1979, most MLB highlights were of these 3 nearby teams; they could be taped off TV
(6, 5).correct response: the Yankees, the Mets & the Red Sox

(0, 0).clue: This term for a sudden piece of good fortune literally refers to fruit blown to the ground
